item.title: NHB sent an invite in April to me, @andpru and several academics from the global South to weigh in on the future of academic publishing. They would publish it without a paywall. None of us coordinated but when I got the proofs a couple of months later... wow! 2/
item.description: NHB sent an invite in April to me, @andpru and several academics from the global South to weigh in on the future of academic publishing. They would publish it without a paywall. None of us coordinated but when I got the proofs a couple of months later... wow! 2/
item.content:encoded: NHB sent an invite in April to me, @andpru and several academics from the global South to weigh in on the future of academic publishing. They would publish it without a paywall. None of us coordinated but when I got the proofs a couple of months later... wow! 2/

item.title: I think the vibe across most editorials is that the traditional academic publishing model is fatally flawed and traditional publishers are extractive, bad for science, scandalous, etc. Pretty bold to read that in the pages of an NPG journal 3/
item.description: I think the vibe across most editorials is that the traditional academic publishing model is fatally flawed and traditional publishers are extractive, bad for science, scandalous, etc. Pretty bold to read that in the pages of an NPG journal 3/
item.content:encoded: I think the vibe across most editorials is that the traditional academic publishing model is fatally flawed and traditional publishers are extractive, bad for science, scandalous, etc. Pretty bold to read that in the pages of an NPG journal 3/

item.title: I made an argument that trad publishers can't deal with a supply shock from an increase in paper submissions due to AI because their peer-reviewing pipeline is already breaking at the seams. It's a bad business model. 4/
item.description: I made an argument that trad publishers can't deal with a supply shock from an increase in paper submissions due to AI because their peer-reviewing pipeline is already breaking at the seams. It's a bad business model. 4/
item.content:encoded: I made an argument that trad publishers can't deal with a supply shock from an increase in paper submissions due to AI because their peer-reviewing pipeline is already breaking at the seams. It's a bad business model. 4/

item.title: FWIW, I think the persistence of peer review+paywall despite obvious flaws is not about aspiration to truth but about exclusivity. Adding up IFs of papers published over the last N years is a rational reaction to lack of domain knowledge (for admins) or time (for academics) 5/
item.description: FWIW, I think the persistence of peer review+paywall despite obvious flaws is not about aspiration to truth but about exclusivity. Adding up IFs of papers published over the last N years is a rational reaction to lack of domain knowledge (for admins) or time (for academics) 5/
item.content:encoded: FWIW, I think the persistence of peer review+paywall despite obvious flaws is not about aspiration to truth but about exclusivity. Adding up IFs of papers published over the last N years is a rational reaction to lack of domain knowledge (for admins) or time (for academics) 5/

item.title: I don't think anybody has cracked that nut yet, and it probably won't be fully resolved until we're in a post-scarcity world where research money is assigned non-competitively. But certain subfields‚Äìphysics, CS, math‚Äìhave extracted themselves from standard publishing 6/
item.description: I don't think anybody has cracked that nut yet, and it probably won't be fully resolved until we're in a post-scarcity world where research money is assigned non-competitively. But certain subfields‚Äìphysics, CS, math‚Äìhave extracted themselves from standard publishing 6/

item.title: Let's keep trying. Let's experiment with bold new ways of publishing science that are more equitable and allow the fruits of publicly funded research to be reaped by the public itself. I'm super excited by new initiatives spearheaded by @neuromatch in this direction 7/7

item.title: The first thing to do is to rasterize the spikes directly as they are plotted and then save the figure as an SVG with dpi=600. This side steps having to make two versions of the figure, one as a SVG or PDF for text and another as a PNG for the spikes.
item.description: The first thing to do is to rasterize the spikes directly as they are plotted and then save the figure as an SVG with dpi=600. This side steps having to make two versions of the figure, one as a SVG or PDF for text and another as a PNG for the spikes.
item.content:encoded: The first thing to do is to rasterize the spikes directly as they are plotted and then save the figure as an SVG with dpi=600. This side steps having to make two versions of the figure, one as a SVG or PDF for text and another as a PNG for the spikes.

item.title: Just add "rasterized=True" to the matplotlib command that you use to plot the spikes. Our lab uses modified code for plotting spike rasters from this gist: https://t.co/Ds5JLyhqZd
item.description: Just add "rasterized=True" to the matplotlib command that you use to plot the spikes. Our lab uses modified code for plotting spike rasters from this gist: https://t.co/Ds5JLyhqZd
item.content:encoded: Just add "rasterized=True" to the matplotlib command that you use to plot the spikes. Our lab uses modified code for plotting spike rasters from this gist: https://t.co/Ds5JLyhqZd

item.title: The second thing is to use the scour library to "scrub" the SVG file. This library is amazing for anyone using Inkscape. No more need to import PDFs or use the deep ungroup function before you get to work. https://t.co/vgyqCWfvB8
item.description: The second thing is to use the scour library to "scrub" the SVG file. This library is amazing for anyone using Inkscape. No more need to import PDFs or use the deep ungroup function before you get to work. https://t.co/vgyqCWfvB8
item.content:encoded: The second thing is to use the scour library to "scrub" the SVG file. This library is amazing for anyone using Inkscape. No more need to import PDFs or use the deep ungroup function before you get to work. https://t.co/vgyqCWfvB8

item.title: This stuff might be common knowledge, but it was news to me. We've been working on a complex figure with a bunch of rasters for a new manuscript and these tricks have made things a lot easier. Hope this is helpful for others.
